objects.name: Moldy Pisces
objects.description:
Moldy Pisces, also known as Reaper, is a suspected North Korean cyber espionage group that has targeted primarily South Korean government, military, defense industrial base, and media sector. In 2017 the group started to target other countries that includes Japan, Vietnam, Nepal, Kuwait, and parts of the Middle East. With their expansion of targets their industry targets expanded as well. 

Moldy Pisces tends to use primarily spear phishing tactics for malware delivery but, this threat group also compromise strategic websites, and use torrent file sharing to distribute their malware.

objects.name: FreeMilk
objects.description: This campaign targeted non-Korean financial institutions, but unlike the other campaigns, this one does not use HWP documents. It instead uses Office documents. Moldy Pisces leveraged the CVE-2017-0199 Microsoft Word Office/WordPad Remote Code Execution Vulnerability with carefully crafted decoy content customized for each target recipient.

objects.name: Evil New Year 2017
objects.description:
In the early part of 2017, Moldy Pisces started the "Evil New Year" campaign. In this campaign, the actors tried to fool victims by pretending the emails were from the Korean Ministry of Unification and that they offered Korean-specific analysis. This campaign began with a handful of spear-phishing emails to South Korean targets and containing malicious attachments. Moldy Pisces further attempted to entice victims to open the attachments by using common Hancom Hangul documents. Hancom's Hangul is a popular Office Suite used primarily in the Korean peninsula. 

The documents sent to the targets were titled "Analysis of "Northern New Year in 2017" and used the official logo of the Korean Ministry of Unification. This is a simple choice for the actor to make, but it further shows their familiarity with the region.

objects.name: North Korea Human Rights
objects.description: In November 2017, Cisco's Talos Intelligence observed the latest Moldy Pisces campaign of the year, which included a new version of ROKRAT being used in the latest wave of attacks. Moldy Pisces again used one of their main calling cards, the malicious HWP document. This time, Moldy Pisces used a document containing information in relation to a meeting held on 1st November in Seoul, South Korea. This document was alleged to have been written by a legal representative claiming to be representing the "Citizens' Alliance For North Korean Human Rights And Reunification Of Korean Peninsula". Moldy Pisces once again uses information related to the Korean unification and now are claiming to highlight concerns related to human rights issues.

objects.name: Evil New Year 2018
objects.description:
At the beginning of 2017, Moldy Pisces started the Evil New Year campaign, in 2018 the threat group did the same campaign that started the 2nd of January. As a Moldy Pisces trademark they sent spearphishing emails with a malicious HWP document. The document contained an analysis of a speech made by the leader of North Korea. The approach is exactly the same as what was seen in 2017 using a new decoy document. This document was alleged to have been written by the Ministry of Reunification. 

This campaigns links the Golden Time campaign, exploiting the EPS vulnerability in HWP documents to download and execute shellcode on a compromised website.

objects.name: Golden Time
objects.description:
Moldy Pisces compromised an email which is part of the Korea Global Forum and sent spear phishing emails praising the user for joining a panel related to "Korea Reunification and North Korean Conference". Another email was sent from a free Korean mail service Daum, Hanmail. The group didn't attempt to make this email official compared ot the other one. The content of the email included a story about someone called "Ewing Kim" that needed help.

Even though email's attachments are two different HWP documents, they both leverage the same vulnerability (CVE-2013-0808) .

Even though email's attachments are two different HWP documents, they both leverage the same vulnerability (CVE-2013-0808) .

objects.name: Golden Time
objects.description:
Moldy Pisces compromised an email which is part of the Korea Global Forum and sent spear phishing emails praising the user for joining a panel related to "Korea Reunification and North Korean Conference". Even though email's attachments are two different HWP documents, they both leverage the same vulnerability (CVE-2013-0808) .
